I could not get a situation, as I could not get a character—I went to the prosecutor to ask him to go to my brother, to ask him to give me a character—he said he would, and we left the house together—I know nothing about the watch—the servant says, that after she had heard the door open and shut once she came down, and saw the door half open—the pro
secutor says he did not return for ten minutes, and he cannot say that in that time some one had not been into the room and taken the watch.
JOHN PRITCHARD . He did not go out with me—his brother was not at the house he sent me to.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1021.
MARY KENNEDY was indicted
for stealing 2 spoons, value 6s. the goods of
Hannah Barbara Lange.

JOHN HENRY LANGE . I am the son of Hannah Barbara Large. She lives in Adam-street, Strand—the prisoner was employed there occasionally as a charwoman for about six months—these spoons are my mother's—we missed them, and found them at the pawnbroker's.

EDWARD GILL . I am shopman to Mr. Turner. a pawnbroker, in Brydge's-street, Covent-garden. These spoons were pawned by the pri
soner on the 13th and 14th of January, in the name of Ryan.
Prisoner. I did through distress—I have three children.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 35.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

div1.p: Confined One Month.

1022.
JOHN PEARCE was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 1st of March, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch chain, value 1s.; and 2 watch keys, value 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Nicholls' which had lately before been stolen by an evil-disposed person, he well knowing the same to have been stolen.

SAMUEL NICHOLAS . I am out of business. I was in Worship-square about half-past one o'clock in the day on the 1st of March, going home—I met a man who snatched out my watch, chain, and seals, and ran down Worship-street—I called "Stop thief," and some persons pursued, but I could not, as I am lame—I went to the pawnbrokers, and gave notice—I saw my watch the same evening.

JOHN BOARDS . I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 42, Shoreditch—on the 1st of March, about ten minutes before four o'clock, the prisoner brought this watch to me to pledge—he asked 30s. on it—I looked at it very hard, and said to my wife, "This is the watch I have received infor
mation about"—the prisoner said, "You have had it before for 30s.—you can lend 30s. on it"—I said, "How came you by it?"—he said it was his own, and he had given 3l. for it, that he had had it six months, and pawned it several times for 30s.—I came to the front to look for an officer, and gave him in charge.

Prisoner. He asked me to tell him the truth, where the watch came from—I said, "A young man, a sailor, stands at the door, who asked me to pawn it, and he said, "If they ask any questions, tell them they have had it before.' "
Witness. I did not ask him to tell the truth.

WILLIAM WEBB (police-constable H 42.) I took the prisoner, and produce this watch—Mr. Boards said, in the hearing of the prisoner, that he had offered it in pledge; and he had received information of one that was stolen, and thought that was it—the prisoner said a man at the door gave it him, and said he would give him 1s. to pledge it for him—there was a young man stood at the door when we came out—the prisoner looked at him. and said that he was not the man.

Prisoner's Defence. I was drawn into the foolishly—the young man ap
peared to me be a sailor—he was 16 or 17 years of age—I was on a sick bed for several days before—I have lived in that neighbourhood for twenty years.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1023.
WILLIAM PRESWICK was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of March, 1 looking glass and stand, value 6s., the goods of
James Crisp; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES M'INTOSH (police-sergeant E 53.) I was in Queen's-row, Pimlico, on the 19th of March, at half-past seven o'clock in the evening—and saw the prisoner with something under his apron—I stopped him, and asked him what he had got—he said, a looking-glass, and a gen
tleman gave him a shilling to take it to the middle arch of Westmin
ster-bridge—I asked him where the gentleman was—he said, "A little way back"—I asked him to go back—he went a little way, and then said he was gone—I took him to the station-house, and found Mr. Crisp, who lives about a mile and a-half from where I took the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you go with the prisoner to Westminster-bridge? A. No, Mr. Crisp lives in Lower Sloane-street—the prisoner said he had been paid for his trouble, and showed me the shilling.

JAMES CRISP . I am a broker, and live in Lower Sloane-street. This glass is mine—it was taken off a bedstead in my shop—it was there at four o'clock in the afternoon, when I went out—I returned late in the evening—it was then gone.
Cross-examined. Q. What time did you get home? A. About nine o'clock—I had not seen the glass for some hours.
WILLIAM DYKE (police-constable R 193.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former indictment, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace
of Westminster—I was a witness on the trial—I know he is the man—(read.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1024.
JOHN HALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of March, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Selby, from his person.

ROBERT SELBY . On the afternoon of the 11th of March, I was passing the end of Bride-lane, Fleet-street—I felt an action at my pocket—I turned and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—I seized him, and gave him to the officer—this is it.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up as I was going along.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

1025.
MARY MURPHY was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 coat, value 10s., the goods of
Arthur James Lewis.

JOSEPH MILBANK . I live in Rawstorne-street, Clerkenwell, and am clerk to Arthur James Lewis—he has chambers there. On the 5th of April I heard a noise on the landing-place of the second floor, where I was sit
ting—I ran out, and saw the prisoner going down stairs—I overtook her on the first floor, and she threw this coat from her—it is my master a, and was taken from the room adjoining, the room I sat in—I gave her into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was that coat in your master's chambers? A. Yes—I saw it about ten minutes before—I did not see a boy on the staircase in a fustian jacket—the door was ajar—I cannot say whether the outer door was ajar—I did not hear any body else go down stairs—I saw the prisoner through the balustrades—she stopped on the first floor, and threw the coat from her—I suppose she saw me.
JURY Q. Did you lose sight of her? A. She got out and went to a public-house—she came out again, and was then taken, as the policeman was waiting for her at the door—I swear she is same woman.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take the coat.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months.

1026.
RICHARD EWEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of March, 2 sacks, value 3s., the goods of
George Schunter.

JAMES STACEY (police-constable H 132.) On the evening of the 28th of March, I was in Webb-square, Shoreditch, about half-past seven o'clock, and saw the prisoner with these two sacks, one under each arm—I asked where he got them—he said they belonged to his father, and he was going to carry them to his uncle—I took him into custody—he then cried, and said he had stolen them from a house in Old-street.
GEORGE SCHUNTER . I live in Gibraltar-walk, Bethnal-green. These are my sacks—they were taken from Old-street-road, where I had sold some flour a short time before.
ANN WINBOLT . I purchased some flour of Mr. Schunter—I left these sacks at Mr. Pritchett's.
JOHN BAILEY . These sacks were stolen from a shed at Mr. Pritchett's, in Old-street.

GUILTY. Aged 12.—Recommended to mercy.—
Whipped and Discharged.

1027.
SOPHIA STUBBS was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 bag, value 2d.; 2 sovereigns, 3 half-crowns. 8 shillings, 7 sixpences, and 4d. in copper money. the goods and monies of
Benjamin Clark, from his person.

BENJAMIN CLARK . I am a green-grocer. On the 5th of April I met the prisoner as near two o'clock as I can recollect—I was the worse for liquor, and hardly recollect any thing about the matter, but I know I had the money in my pocket when I met the prisoner in Bow-street—I went with her to a house, No 8, Charles-street, Drury-lane—I had then three so
vereigns, and a little other money, but I cannot recollect what—I laid down on the bed—I had not given the prisoner any money—I was awoke about four o'clock by the mater of the house—the prisoner was then gone, and my money also—the master of the house had given me change for a so
vereign.

THOMAS KEENE . I am landlord of the house. I remember the pri
soner coming there, with the witness, about two o'clock on Tuesday morning—the prisoner had lodged there about six months—she took the prosecutor to her room, and as they were passing the passage, the prosecu
tor asked if I would give him change for a sovereign—I gave him three half-crowns, and the rest in small silver—I did not see that he had any other sovereigns—he then went up-stairs, and in the course of an hour after. wards (I had fastened the street door) I heard somebody coming down stairs—I opened my door, and saw the prisoner coming down, with her shoes in her hand—I asked where she was going—she said to get some gin—I said she should not go out till I saw that her friend was all right, knowing that he had had change of me—I then double-locked the door, went up-stairs, and tried to awake the prosecutor, but I could not—he was in bed, and I saw his clothes—he had no money left—I came down, and accused the prisoner, who was by the door, of robbing him of the change of a sovereign—she said he gave her 5s., which was all the money she had—I sent for an officer, but previous to the officer coming, she said she did not want to rob him, and sooner than I should give her in charge, she would give me a bag containing 19s. 4d., and a silk handkerchief—the officer then came, and took hold of her throat, and two sovereigns came from her mouth into his hand.

PHILLIP COSTIN . I am a police-constable. On the morning of the 5th of April I was sent for between three and four o'clock—the prisoner was in the witness's room, and he gave me a bag containing 19s. 4d.—I saw there was something in the prisoner's throat—I seized her, and she gave me out two sovereigns.
BENJAMIN CLARK . This handkerchief if mine.

Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the money to take care off till the morning—it was not my intention to rob him, but so many persons coming in, I thought it was the best way to take it down with me—he had asked me to get something for supper, and to take the handkerchief to put it in—I delivered him (the landlord) all the silver and the handkerchief—I said, "I shall not let you have the two sovereigns"—I put them in my month.
GUILTY. of stealing, but not from the person. Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years.

1028.
WILLIAM LEDGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of March, 1 safety value, value 2l., the goods of
Squire Night, and others.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1029.
GEORGE CARTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 3 saddles, value 40s.; 1 pair of traces, value 5s.; 1 pair of hames, value 5s.; 1 breeching, value 10s.; 1 bridle, value 10s.; 1 pair of reins, value 4s.; 1 martingale, value 1s.; and 1 horse-cloth, value 4s.; the goods of
Louis Panormo.

LOUIS PANORMO . I am a musical-instrument maker, and live in High-street, St. Giles. I lost this property from a stable which I rent in Falcon
bery-court—I had seen it safe in the morning of the 4th of April—I was sent for by Mr. Fox, at a quarter before nine o'clock in the evening—I found the padlock had been broken, and the stable was stripped—there were marks of an instrument by which it had been broken—this is my property.

WILLIAM FOX . I am a barman. At a quarter before nine o'clock last Monday evening I was in Falconberry-court, and saw a man coming out of the stable with a whip—the prisoner then came out with a bag of harness—I called to him and asked what he had got—he made no answer—I then collared him, and took him to the Three Tuns, where I reside—I sent for the prosecutor, who claimed the property.
SAMUEL GODDARD (police-Sergeant F 13.) I took the prisoner and the property.
Prisoner's Defence. I was quite in distress—I really did not know what to do—I had been out of a situation for some time.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1030.
MATILDA DE BOILET was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of March, 1 knife, value 2s.; 1 fork, value 2s.; 2 spoons, value 6s.; 1 brooch, value 10s.; 1 towel, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 18s.; and 5 yards of merino, value 10s.; the goods of
William Jenner.

WILLIAM JENNER . I live in Grove-street, Commercial-road. I have known the prisoner about two years—she lived in my house for six or seven weeks, like one of my family—on the 23rd of March, I and my wife went to a sale opposite Whitechapel church—I left the prisoner at home with a young man, who works in the room—I returned about five or six o'clock in the evening—the prisoner was then gone, and did not return at all—I missed a pair of trowsers from a box, and from the table drawer, which had been locked, and of which my wife had the key in her pocket, I missed the other articles.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How often have you allowed her to pawn things for you? A. Never—not once—when she came to me, she came as a binder, I am a shoemaker—I got her work, but she was discharged, as she did not to work enough—I work for Mr. Kirby, opposite Whitechapel church—I have no houses—I sold them at Lady-day—I had some in King-street, Commercial-road—that street is full of "accomodation houses"—I kept the houses as such, but I did not know what they were when I paid the deposit-money—I went to the Pavilion one night with my wife and the prisoner—the prisoner pressed me to send my wife home, and as I was rather fresh, the prisoner took me unawares—I do not know of any other time that she pressed me to leave my wife and family—I never had much to do with her since—I never went with her to one of my own houses.

GEORGE WALKER JUDGE . I am a police surveyor. I took the pri
soner at Newington, and asked he what she had done with the things she took from Mr. Jenner—she said she had pawned them, and burnt the duplicates—I asked her if she knew any thing of a child's petticoat and
towel, pledged at Mr. Latter's—she first denied it, and then said she did—Mrs. Jenner gave me the duplicates, which she said she found under the prisoner's bed.
GEORGE GILL . I am a pawnbroker. I have two remnants of merino, pawned by a female—I cannot say who.
SARLE WHITLOW . I have a child's petticoat and a napkin, pawned by Elizabeth Adams—not by the prisoner.
GEORGE WORLEY . I have a knife, fork, two tea-spoons, and a brooch, pawned by a female—I cannot say whether it was the prisoner.

MARYAN JENNER . I am the prosecutor's wife. I found this duplicate under the bolster of the prisoner's best—this property is mine, and there was a great deal more, which we cannot find—I never gave her leave to pawn any thing.

Cross-examined. Q. When you had any thing to pledge, you did it yourself? A. Yes, always—I have pawned when we wanted money—the prisoner was sometimes out till nine or ten, or sometimes twelve o'clock at night—she has brought home money to me—I never asked her where she got it—my husband had five houses in King-street.

COURT. Q. Do not you know that the prisoner went with men? A. Yes—she came to us, and said she would get binding or umbrella-making—we always kept her—sometimes she gave me a shilling—the largest sum was 6s., and part of that was my husband's money, that she had of him.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: Third Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1031.
HENRY HOOPER was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
John Middleton Hare, from his person.

JOHN MIDDLETON HARE . I am an editor of a newspaper. On Good Friday evening, I was in Church-street, Bethnal-green—I felt something at my pocket—I turned round and saw the prisoner drop my handkerchief from his hand—I took it up, secured him, and gave him into custody di
rectly.

(Property produced and sworn to.) Prisoner. Three or four boys ran across the road—the gentleman came and collared me directly. Witness. There was another boy, but the pri
soner had the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1032.
JAMES HUTCHINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 2 brushes, value 5s.; and 2 razors, value 4s.; the goods of
Charles John Parke.

JAMES CHRISTOPHER EVANS . I am a Thames police-officer. On the 4th of April, I met the prisoner in Hermitage-street, St. George's and ap
prehended him on another charge—I took him to the office, and between the waistband of his trowsers and his shirt, there were two hair brushes—I asked where he got them from—he said he bought them before he went to sea, and took them to Barbadoes for speculation—that he could not sell them, and was going to take them back—I asked where he bought them—he said of a Jew, but he could not find him—he said he belonged to the
Tropic—I went on board the vessel, and found the prosecutor—I searched the prisoner's chest, and found the razors in a pocket of a pair of trowsers in his box.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you took him for having tobacco which had not paid the duty? A. Yes; and he was fined 10s.—the prosecutor said he did not wish to hurt him—he did not say they used to borrow each other's things.

CHARLES JOHN PARKE . I am a sailor on board the Tropic, which came from Barbadoes. The prisoner had belonged to that vessel—the had gone on shore on this day—these brushes and razors are mine, and were taken from my chest on board the ship—it was not locked.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had he sailed with you? A. This was the third voyage—we were good fiends—we did not borrow each other's things—he conducted himself well—I said I did not wish to hurt him, but I was obliged to prosecute him.

GUILTY. Aged 38.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Eight Days.

1033.
GEORGE HARRIS was indicted
for stealing a quantity of indigo, the property of
the London-dock Company; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1034.
JAMES DUNCAN was indicted for
feloniously breaking and en
tering the dwelling-house of
William Chaplin, on the 21st of March, at St. Andrew, Holborn, and stealing therein 16 half-crowns, 60 shilling, and 40 sixpences, the monies of
James Maskell; and 8 sovereigns, 1 half so
vereign, and 15 shillings, the monies of the said William Chaplin; and
JAMES FALLEN
for feloniously and maliciously inciting and procuring the said
James Duncan to commit the said felony.

JOHN FLETCHER . I was waiting about at the White Horse, in Fetter-lane, for jobs, about half-past four o'clock on Tuesday morning, the 22nd of March, and I caught hold of a chap's stick who was in a coach—I said to him, "Is your name Hoppe?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "You have no business here at al"—I knew both the prisoners by sight before that morning—I saw Duncan in the York coach—he had no business there—he was not employed there—I shut the door, and shut him in—he was alone—he said his mother had locked him out.

JAMES MASKELL . I am book-keeper at the White Horse. I left on Monday evening, the 21st of March, about a quarter before ten o'clock—the office is up the yard, and is part of the house, but there is no inlet to the office but from the yard—there is no communication with the dwelling-house, except by going through the yard—you must come out into the yard to go the house—there is simply a covered way from the office to the tavern, so that you can pass along without going into the rain—it is part of the house—the rooms over the officer are bed-rooms for gentlemen stop
ping at the tavern—when I went away at night, I left my desk double locked, and a bar of iron went inside the lid of the desk through the bottom of the desk, where there is a plate of iron which fastens with a padlock—I left the porter in the office when I left—his name is Greenland—he is not here—there was £6 silver, loose in the desk—there were two parcels also which seemed to contain money, which had come by the coach that evening, and which I placed in the desk.

for security—I do not know myself what they contained—there was also some silver in a bag which was not taken, as something last over it—I was sent for between six and seven o'clock next morning by the porter, and found the desk had evidently been forced open—the padlock had been forced, the tongue of it wrenched up so as to allow the how of the padlock to pass it, and the brass work of the desk-lock had been forced—I missed those parcels and the loose sil
ver—I examined the office-door—that had not been forced—I made in
quiry, and on questioning Fletcher, in consequence of what he said, I went in quest of Duncan, and gave him into custody—I found him in the passage of his mother's lodging—the officer searched him, in my presence, and in his boot found four shillings, two of them were new—he told me something at the station-house—I made him no threat or promise—it was entirely voluntary—the officer told me he was crying—when I entered the station-house he was crying, and as soon as he saw me, he said, "I did it, Mr. Maskell, and will tell you all about it"—he said he got into the York coach, which was brought from the coach-factory, and stood in the lane—that he got inside the coach, and remained there till it was drawn into the yard again, at the gates being closed, and at one o'clock he got out, and let himself into my office with a key that he had got—that he took a poker and forced the padlock, and then forced the desk and took the two parcels and the money—that he had been instigated to do it by another boy—he said that he had got a light with some matches and a candle, and that when he had done it, he got out and got into the York coach, where Fletcher saw him, and remained there till the gates were opened, and was drawn in the coach into Fetter-lane—that he then got out, and went to the house of another boy not in custody, and opened the parcel—took out the money and placed it in a cream-jug, to remain there till the matter had blown over—that he took five shillings and spent one, and the remaining four shillings, were in his boot—he said one parcel contained sovereigns, half-sovereigns, and five shillings, which he afterwards corrected, and side was seven shillings—and the other parcel contained a good deal of money—he did not know how much—that they placed all the money in a cream-jug, to save it till it had blown over—he formerly had something to do at our yard—the principal park of the loose silver in my desk was new money, and two of the four shilling found on him were new.

JOSEPH SHAW . I am a policeman. I received Duncan in charge from Maskell—I searched him, and found four shillings in the boot of his left leg—I was present when he mentioned the particulars to Maskell—I have heard what he has stated, it is correct—he told me the same thing before, but not exactly in the same words—I made him no promise or threat—I went to Plough-court, and, while I was watching, Fallen came down stairs—there was another officer there, and he gave him into custody—Fallen told me that he stole the key of the office and gave it to Duncan, on the Saturday morning—this was after his first examination, as I was taking him from the justice-room to the Compter—I had not promised or threatened him in any way.

CHARLES WALLER . I am a city policeman. I found a key at a house in Wych-street, Strand, behind a water-butt, where Hagger lived, who is not apprehended—I showed the key to Duncanhe said it was the key which he took to Hagger's house with the two parcels of the money—I took it to the office, and it fitted the door.

JAMES MASKELL
re-examined. The covered passage leads from the of
fice

door to the tavern door—it is brought forwards from the building to the coaches, that passengers may alight without being in the rain—the co
vered way is not enclosed—one side is the wall of the house, and the other side is exposed to the yard—it is supported by posts, but not enclosed—there is no door communicating from the office into the house—you must go under the passage way, under cover.
Duncan. I broke the desk open—I was forced by Hagger, and brought into a bad line to do it.
Fallen. This boy asked me to get the key—I did not know what he was going to do.
Duncan. Yes he did.

DUNCAN—
GUILTY of Larceny only. Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years.

FALLEN—
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gaselee.

1035.
JAMES BARNES was indicted
for embezzling and stealing, on the 2nd of March, the sum of 6s. 4d., 4d., and 2s. 6d., which he had re
ceived by virtue of his employment in his Majesty's Post Office.—11 other COUNTS, varying the manner of laying the charge.
MESSRS. SHEPHERD, ADOLPHUS, and SCARLETT conducted the prosecution.

WASTELL ARROWSMITH . I am a clerk in the Foreign Office of the Post Office; the prisoner was one of the Presidents of that office, and had the control over the inferior officers. I received instructions respecting the prisoner, which made my attention to him more exact, and my memory more accurate—letters received at the receiving-houses, in different parts of the town, for inland and foreign delivery, are made up in bags for the evening, to he delivered at the Post Office—it often happens that Colonial letters are put into the foreign instead of the inland bags—(the evi
dence given by the witness in the former case, page 1016, as to the routine of business at the Post Office, was here read to him, which he confirmed.)—when letters come by mistake into the Foreign Office, they are sent to the Inland Office, by a tunnel, with the money—the money ought not to come into the hands of the President—he ought to send the letters by a messenger to the bag-clerk—that is the usual course of the office—the prisoner had been in the habit of coming himself, in
stead of sending a messenger, to get the money—I had been spoken to to pay particular attention to Mr. Barnes—on Wednesday evening, the 2nd of March, I was on duty as window-clerk—I came on duty between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, and remained on duty all day till half-past seven—the prisoner came to me, about a quarter before five o'clock, with three letters, which he said were to go

into the Inland Office, and it required 6s. 4d. as the postage—he also read out the amounts of the postage of each letter—one amounted to 1s. 2d.—I cannot say where it was for, but it was very peculiarly marked—I am swear to the appear
ance of the letter—the others were 2s. 2d. and 3s. (looking at a letter)—I believe this is the 1s. 2d. letter, as far as I can state—it has a penny-post mark on it, which is another thing which made me notice it—it was a busy might at the office; but at the time he brought me the letters I was not doing any thing at all—I gave him 6s. 4d.—he came about five minutes after, and brought two newspapers, which he said were going to the Mauritius and Madras—he got 4d. for them—he came again be-seven and eight o'clock, and asked me for 2s. 2d. for a letter which was to go into the Inland Office—I think he mentioned that it was to go to Nova Soctia✗—I told him, as I had not a letter agreeing with the amount 2s. 2d., he must go to the examiner of the bags, Mr. James—a Nova Scotia letter would property go to the inland office—I was present on Saturday, the 5th of March, at Mr. Peacock's office, when the prisoner was examined—Mr. Peacock came down to the Foreign Office, and he went up with him—Mr. Peacock asked him whether he had forwarded letters which he had been in the habit of coming for the postage for to the Inland Office—he said, "Yes, of course"—he was asked if he had any letters in his drawer—he said, "No"—he was asked if he had any about his person—he said, "No"—when he was told he would be searched, he acknowledged that he had some in his drawer—he was told by the solicitor it would be necessary to hare his person and drawer searched; and he said, a short time afterwards, "Now you ask me particularly, I recollect I have four or five letters in my drawer'—he never said he had any about him that I recollect—two foreign letters were found on his person.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. How long have you been a clerk in the Post Office? A. About three years and a half—I am very conver
sant with the general routine of the Post Office duties—I expect to rise. as we are in the habit of doing, as vacancies occur—when a President is re
moved, I come rather near the presidency—Mr. Barnes's situation pro
duced him about 500l. a year, I rather think—he has always been consi
dered a very able, intelligent gentleman, and an excellent officer, knowing the duties of the Post Office very well—but not performing them.

Q. Do you mean to tell us this gentleman was not active, able offi
cer who performed his duties well? A. Yes, I do—I have been frequently with him in the office—it was his business to superintend my conduct—it does not occur to me not to make mistakes—the duties are not extremely intricate—it requires no skill or experience at all to make up bun
dles of letters—it requires to he done with great expedition on busy days—the business ought all to be completed by twelve o'clock—Mr. Barnes has assisted the junior clerks on busy nights—in doing so, he has undoubtedly done more than his own personal duty—it is the usual way to sent the money through the hands of a messenger with the letters to go to the Inland Office—it is the usual and proper way with a president—when Mr. Barnes did it, it would alleviate the duty of the messenger—Mr. Barnes would be entitled to transfer the money he receives for the postage through the tunnel by the hand of a messenger—he was not compelled to carry them to the tunnel himself—if I had been disengaged I would have done it, if he had asked me—we are all together in the office, but not pro
miscously—the messengers are on one side, and the clerks on the other—there are fire places in the office, round one of which we(the clerks) gather, and the messengers round the other—the President and clerks mix round the fire—the messengers are in the habit of stirring our fire—the messen
gers are not allowed to come and sit with us—they come when we send for them—I do not know whether the President gives security to the Crown for the situation he holds—I am in the habit of attending the window, but I am not called the window clerk—it I a term used among us—there are seven of us altogether—Mr. Barnes may have sent the money to the tun
nel by any of the inferior clerks—probably if he had asked a President he would not have objected; hut there being only one President on duty, he could not ask him—there are two Presidents, and a superintending Presi
dent in the office—there are sixteen clerks.

Q. Now you say Mr. Barnes was in the habit of coming to you for these letters, did you ever refuse him on any occasion? A. Never—the usual course is to send a messenger—I could not object to Mr. Barnes having the money and letters from me—he might think proper to send the messenger to the tunnel—my business finished about thirty five minutes after seven o'clock, on the 2nd of March—I think Mr. Barnes finished about eight o'clock—I can say it is before twelve o'clock—his duty would finish at eleven o'clock—that was the time of their leaving every night, except post nights—that is the time they are authorized to leave—on Tuesdays sad Fridays they are sometimes there till after twelve o'clock—he is not obliged to sleep at the Post Office on Tuesdays and Fridays—I cannot tell whether he slept there on the Wednesday night—there is a bed room and sitting room on purpose for the President—I believe Mr. Barnes has a wife and family, and a house in the country—I know he has been in the habit of sleeping at the Post Office on busy night.

COURT, Q. What time do you go away? A. On Tuesdays and Fri
days at twelve o'clock—on other nights it varies—I always sleep there myself.

MR. PRICE. Q. When Mr. Barnes came to you for the letters, he came at a time when you were particularly at leisure? A. Yes, when I had no
thing to do at all—I was not employed on any thing at the time—my at
tention was not then drawn by any important office business—that did not give me an opportunity of examining the letters particularly—I could have done it—he came to me the second time about five minutes after—he might have come at a time when I was more fully employed; and he did so, between seven and eight o'clock—he was first asked in the So
licitor's Office whether he had forwarded the letters he had been in the habit of receiving the postage on—I was asked at Bow street what he said at Mr. Peacock's office—I do not think I made the same statement on that occasion—I answered the questions that were asked me.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You have been asked about the views you have in this prosecution; does it make any difference to you in your he pas or your situation, whether the prisoner is convicted or acquitted? A. None whatever—he is already removed from the office, and a successor appointed—whatever may happen to day, I shall be no more backward of forward in my appointment.

MR. PRICE. Q. Was Mr. Barnes asked about money?—have you told us all that was said to him in the solicitor's office—have you told us all that passed? A. He was asked if he forwarded the letters on Friday with the money—there are colonial letters almost daily—letters for Madras and Mauritius, and other colonial places, frequentle come to the Foreign Office.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Have the mistakes, which you say have occurred, occurred when Mr. Barnes was President, or when any body else was Pre
sident? A. Both—no mistake was ever made by me which subjected me to any police inquiry—there is no great nicety required in conducting let
ters through the tunnel—there is a person appointed to do it—if any body else chose to do it, he has nothing to do but walk to the tunnel and put it in—the messenger merely comes to our fire place when called, and leaves again—the number of window clerks on duty at the same time varies—there was none besides myself on duty on the 2nd of March—I was the only window clerk that night—Mr. Barnes did not order me to take the letter and money to the tunnel—I did not hear anybody ordered to do so—the tunnel closed that evening at eight o'clock—he had from

five to eight o'clock to send the letters through the tunnel—i said nothing to him about receiving letters out of the usual course, because I had no bu
siness to interfere with a superior officer.

COURT. Q. Suppose the President had sent the messenger to the bag-man, and the bagman had received the money and the letter, what would be the messenger's duty? A. He would take it, with the money, to the tunnel, and put it into the box to be conveyed over—that is the usual course—he would leave the foreign letter with Mr. Barnes, and take the money and inland letters to the tunnel—it would be the messenger's duty to take the money and the inland letter to the tunnel—he might or might not have to carry the foreign letter, it might be handed to him by the bagman himself—he might take the foreign letter to the President.
MR. SCARLETT. Q. When foreign letters are brought into the office, ought they not, in the common course of duty to be forwarded the same night? A. They ought to be forwarded the same night.

FREDERICK DIXON JAMES . I am a clerk in the Foreign Post Office. On the 2nd of March, between seven and half-past seven o'clock, the prisoner came to me to ask for the postage of one letter and two newspapers—the postage of the letter was 2s.2d.—I have a distinct recollection of that—the newspapers were 2d. each—I delivered him the money—I cannot my whether it is the usual course of duty for the President or messenger to bring the letters to receive the postage for—the other President receives them by a messenger—the letters on which I paid the postage were intended for the Inland Office—I remember placing a letter on the table behind me for the messenger to take to the Inland Office—it was addressed to the name of Teasdale—I do not recollect whether it was Mr. or Mrs.—I sent 8d., the postage, with the letter—there is an officer of the name of Teasdale in the Foreign Office—I do not know whether the letter was written by him—it is usual for clerks in the Foreign Office to transmit their letters for the Inland Office through the tunnel (looking at a letter)—the postage on this letter is 2d.,—it is addressed to "W. L. Mellish, Esq., Rifle Bri
gade, Halifax, Nova Scotia"—it bears the Foreign Office stamp,—accor
ding to the stamp, it came into the office on the 2nd of March—this news
paper (looking at one) is addressed to "A. M'Lean, Esq., Civil Service Madras"—it bears the stamp of the Foreign Office, according to which, it came into the Foreign Office on the 29th of February—the postage of that is 2d.—this letter addressed to "Hev. Ham, Curacoa, "bears the Foreign Office stamp—that came into the Foreign Office on the 29th of February—and this, addressed to "New South Wales," came on the 20th of February—letters coming to the Foreign Office ought to be forwarded the same night—I am acquainted with these stamps—I have examined the letters, with the marks and signs used by the Post Office, to ascertain that they came into the office on those dates.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long have you been a clerk in the Post Office? A. Four years—there are some nights in the Post Office much more busy than others—I do not recollect whether the 2nd of March was a heavy night or not—it might have been very heavy that night—(the night-charge book was here produced.)

Q. Look at this book, can you tell me whether there was not made up on that night the Malta, the Indian Brazil, and Buenos Ayres monthly mails, in addition to the other business? A. Some part of them were made up such letters as were not dispatched on the previous Saturday—I mean letters which came in after the Saturday, as the mails were detained—that

would render the Wednesday night rather more busy than ordinary—I did not consider I was doing wrong in leaving the letter and postage on the table for the messenger to take—the president might, in the dis
charge of his duty, leave a letter and the postage on a table for the mes
senger to take)—I cannot say how long my letter remained on the table be
fore the messenger took it—I did not see it taken—I cannot tell what mes
senger took it—it would have been the duty of any messenger, passing that way, to take it, and put it into the tunnel—if Mr. Barnes had asked any of the clerks to put it into the tunnel, they would of course done so—there are sixteen clerks in the office, including the Presidents, and four messengers—I did not have the letters in my hand to read when Mr. Barnes spoke to me—I have not the slightest idea whether these are the letters or newspapers.

MR. SCARLETT. Q. You have been asked about a press of busi
ness on this particular night—if there was, would it not save the time of the President to employ a messenger, instead of going himself to demand the postage? A. Yes, if the messenger was not engaged at the time.

COURT. Q. You say it would be the duty of any messenger to take this letter—do you mean any messenger who happened to be going that way? A. The messengers are continually coming in to carry the empty bags, and we always send letters by them to the tunnel—if he sees a letter lying there, he might take it and the money, without being directed—I do not know that this is his duty—we usually direct them—I called for a messenger to take the letter which I put behind me, with the postage—we do not allow a messenger to take a letter from behind us without being directed to do so—it was Mr. Teasdale's letter that I put behind me—no letter coming to the Post Office in the usual way could arrive at the Inland Office through the Foreign Office, without the directions of the President or my
self, as the opener of the bag—a letter written in the office would go by my directions, by putting the postage on the table—the President might have sent either of these letters in any way he thought fit.
MR. PRICE. Q. Does not the maker up of the bundle occasionally send a messenger for the money, without the knowledge of the President? A. I never heard of such a circumstance.

RICHARD CRADDOCK . On Wednesday evening, the 2nd of March, I was on duty at the tunnel, on the Inland Office—it is my duty to receive the letters and postage, which come from the Foreign Office to the Inland Office by the tunnel—I went on duty at a quarter before five o'clock, and left at eight o'clock—I was induced to pay particular attention that even
ing to the letters and postage which came through—I received one private letter, belonging to a clerk in the office, with the postage of 8d.—it was addressed to Teasdale, of Bognor, and I think Mrs. Teasdale—there is a clerk in the Foreign Post Office, of the name of Teasdale—it is the custom of the clerks to transmit their letters in that way—I receive them fre
quently in that way—I received two newspapers on that evening for the Ship-letter Office—the postage was 2d—I did not notice their address, more than that they were for the Ship-letter Office—I did not receive any postage of 6s.4s., nor of 4d. that evening—I received no other postage than what I have stated—the tunnel closes at eight o'clock—I remained there till the tunnel closed.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. At which end is the tunnel closed? A. The inland end—I work the boxes by machinery—there are two boxes—one goes to the Foreign Office, while the other box comes from it—when

I close my door there is still a box at the foreign end—I do not knows when I close my door whether the door at the foreign end is open on closed—if any thing was thrown into the box at the foreign end after I left, it must remain there till the following morning—they do not work the tunnel at the other end—I am in attendance every day—I was not on duty the following morning—mistakes do occur, which are rectified in the course of the evening—I never knew it happen that a letter was found in the box the next morning—the tunnel works from six to eight o'clock, which is the time when the Post Office is most engaged—there had been short postage sent with letters by mistake, and we have returned an answer to the Foreign Office, that they have sent the postage so much short, and they have sent the money to make it up—I do not know whether there is any officer superintending at the foreign end of the tunnel to take an account of what goes through—I believe the letter and money are put in by different officers at the other end, but at out end there is only one—I keep no account of what comes through the tunnel—I take the money and letter to that part of the office they are to go to—some to the paid window, others to the Ship-letter Office—there is no check kept on my accuracy to my knowledge—there is no ticket or note of the money or letters accompanying them—the Ship-letter Office is one one side of my room, and the paid window on the other—if a colonial letter comes through the tunnel from the Foreign Office, I take it to the window, and state, "This is from the Foreign Office, and there is the postage"—Bullbeck, the other messenger, was on duty following morning.

MR. SHEPHERD. Q. You receive the letters and money through the tunnel and them to their proper places, and account to the person you take them to, how you obtain them? A. Yes—the runnel is worked on my side—they can only work it on the foreign side by pulling a cord, which is not the usual way—we have a bell on each side—if they want to send any thing to me they ring the bell, and if I want to send to them I do the same.

CHARLES BULLBECK . I am a messenger in the Post Office. It is my duty at attend at the tunnel on alternate days—I was there on Thursday, the 3rd of March—I went at six o'clock in the morning—there was no letters or postage in the box that morning, I am quite certain.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. How long do you remain on duty? A. Till about nine o'clock in the morning on the average—it depends on when the duty ceases—i am there about hours—when we leave the duty is over till evening entirely.

GEORGE LEADBITTER . I am a police-officer. I was present at the Post Office when the prisoner was examined by Mr. Peacock—Mr. Peacock asked him if he had any letters in his drawer—(that was the first question I heard; I was not present at first)—he said he would tell the truth—I had not gone into the room till some after the prisoner was there—I found these letter in his drawer—(producing the same letter as on the former trial.)

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe these papers and letters you produced on Saturday also? A. I did—I found the keys of the drawer on his person—he pointed out key which would open his drawer—the first thing I heard him say was, "I will tell the truth"—I did not use the words on Saturday, but the meaning was the same.
Q. Did you use the words on Saturday, as coming from him, "I will tell the truth?" A. No—I said on Saturday, that the said he had

letters and papers in his drawer—it did not occur at me to mention that he said he would tell the truth—I was examine at Bow-street—I did not mention it there—it occurred to me after my examination on Saturday—I examined Mr. Barnes' house—he had not any opportunity of going to it, before searched it—I found an official book and some Post Office official papers—I searched his private apartments at the office, and found a quan
tity of papers.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Where is the house you searched? A. At Peck
ham, Rye, about six miles from the Office.

WASTELL ARROWSMITH
re-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Is there not a certain sum of the public money which the official clerks in the office have access to and may use? A. For official purpose—I cannot tell whethers there is any authority for using it—it has been a practice ever since I was in the office—it is necessary—the money is entrusted to the junior—he is answerable for it to the post-master—it is allowed to him for official par
poses, by the superintending President—it is 40l., I believe at present—it used to be 35l. when I was junior—it is used for the purpose of returning over-charges on letter and other official purpose—there are letter charged to him, coming by the mails from France and other places—he is to pay the money with which he is changed on these mornings, on a certain day—three days in a week, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

Q. Is any part of that money lent to the junior clerks? A. It has been, though that is at his own risk—he is answerable for it—I have myself bor
rowed some of that money, for my own purpose—it is borrowed by the senior as well as by the junior—Mr. Barnes himself has borrowed it.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How often does the junior clerk account for the money in his possession? A. How often does the junior clerk accounted for once a week—it is given by one junior to his successor—we get the return of the overcharges once a week, and always keep up the sum—that been no
things at all to do with called upon through the tunnel.

(The prisoner being called upon for his defence, contended that by the 5th and 6th William IV, caput 25, sects. 8, 17, 28, and 24, he was authorised to exercise a discretionary power in the mode of transmitting letters—that on the night in question several addition mails required to be made up, which caused an immense pressure of business, and induced him to render his assistance in those inferior departments which his duty not require—that on retiring to bed, after every lock in the office was secured, he ob
served that two single letters were left, out, which were of no consequences, there being no postage on them, they being directed for ordinary seaman—he placed them in his pocket, for security, till the morning—that if the money, stated by the witnesses as paid to him, ever came into his hands, he must have forwarded it with letters to the Inland-office—he further stated, that the junior clerks had an interest in his removal, as they would thereby be advanced—and contended that it must be evident he should never have had the folly or madness to risk his situation of 500l. per annum, after twenty-seven years service, as well as his character and the interests of his wife and family, for so paltry a sum. The same witnesses deposed to his good character as on the former trial.)
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1036.
SARAH CLACKHORN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of March, 2 shoes, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 6d., 1 shift, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 1s.; 1 saucepan, value 1s.; and 1 shawl, value 3d.; the goods of
Edward Dale; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

1037.
WILLIAM JACKSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 1 till, value 2s.; 9s., 6 sixpence., and 12 half-pence; the goods and monies of
Joseph Burton; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

1038.
JOHN HUGHES was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 3 knives, value 6d.; and 3 forks, value 6d.; the goods of
John Cann; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Weeks.

1039.
JOHN CREED was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 4 pairs of sheets, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph Bark.

JOSEPH CORPSE . I am servant to Joseph Bark of Shadwell. On the 24th of April, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, an opposite neighbour gave me information that a boy had taken four pairs of shoes—I has been absent about five minutes—he brought the prisoner to me with the shoes—these are them—they had hung at the door post.
ENNEIS M'ALLEN . I am a policeman. The prisoner was given into my charge with the shoes.

CHARLES CRAVENER . I live directly opposite the prosecutor—I looked out at my door, and saw the prisoner receive these shoes in his pinafore from another boy opposite the shop—they both ran off—I pursued, and brought the prisoner back with them—the other boy was rather less than him.

GUILTY . Aged 11—
Whipped and Discharged.

1040.
WILLIAM HIGGINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 1lb. of bacon, value 7d., the goods of
Joseph Russell.

JOSEPH RUSSELL . I am a cheesemonger, and live in High-street, Shad
well. On the 7th of April, about ten o'clock in the day, the prisoner passed my window, and put his hand on the shopboard with his apron own it—a person said he bad taken a bit of bacon—I ran after him, and caught him with it in his hand, four or five yards off—I gave him in charge.

Prisoner's Defence. A boy came running by me, and threw the bacon into the road, and ran off—Mr. Russell laid hold of me—a gentleman said, "It is not him, the boy is gone on"—he immediately said he would make me pay for it.
MR. RUSSELL. It is not tune—he had the bacon is his hand when I collared him, and he threw it the road.

GUILTY .* Aged 16—
Transported for Seven Years.

1041.
MARY ANN BROOKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 1 shirt value 2s.; 2 night caps, value 1s.; 8 handkerchiefs, value 12s.; 1 ring, value 2s.; 27 plates, value 6s.; 2 books value 1s.; 1 brush, value 1s.; 8 stocking, value 3s.; 3 dishes, value 1s.; 1 pin cushion, value 1s.; 1 rule value 1s.; 2 night gowns, value 6s.; 1 towel, value 1s.; and 1 pillow-case, value 2s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Richard
son, her mistress.
ELIZABETH RICHARDSON . I live I Cochrane-tenace, St. John's-wood.

The prisoner has been in my service for twelve months as servant of all work—I intended to part with her—I received a letter which raised my sus
picions—I missed articles, and found she was carrying things out of my house—I stopped her last Tuesday going out, as she said, to her sister's funeral—she had a cloak on—I saw it was very bulky—I said, "Come here, take off your cloak, and let me see what you have in your pocket"—she was then in the front parlour—she had her bonnet on going out—when I spoke to her, she ran into the bed-room, threw the cloak on the bed, and began taking things out of her pocket—she took three shirts out—she kicked two under the bed, and I took hold of the other, but I took out of her pocket some of the articles named in the indictment—I sent for a policeman, who took her to the station-house—she had put a small ear-ring in a pill
box under a pillow at the time—she was let go for two days to go to her sister's funeral, and when she came back, the magistrate said I had better have her box searched—I found she had packed it full of china out of a crate—every thing in her box was mine—I was moving from a house I have, and had my china in a crate.

WILLIAM LLOYD . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into cus
tody—I never saw the shirts—I was sent to the prosecutrix's house—the prisoner had been stopped, and her mistress gave me a night-shirt and other articles, and a small ring, which I found on the table—I took her before the Magistrate, and from the prosecutrix's kindness she was allowed to go to her sister's funeral, and her mistress engaged to produce her on the Friday morning—when she came before the Magistrate, he asked if I had searched her boxes—I then went to the house, searched her boxes, and found a number of plates, clothes, brushes, and other articles—here are some plates and dishes—the things were in five boxes.
Prisoner. Q. Where did you find all these different things? A. In her different boxes—I found the apparel in a box by itself.

ELIZABETH RICHARDSON
re-examined. This crockery and these other things are all mine.

Prisoner's Defence. Her son-in-law gave me the stockings when we lived in York-terrace—the prosecutrix removed three times—she always allowed me to put the things into my box when we moved, as she had not many boxes—when we moved once the plate was put into the plate-box, and the china was put into my box, as the crate would not hold it—she told me whatever I might not be able to put into the crate, to put into my box, as we could get them out when wanted—she left the care of the linen to me—on Saturday I had a letter from my brother, saying my sister was ill, and wanting me to leave—on Tuesday, master was shaving, and said, "Bring me a clean shirt before you go," and mistress said, "Put out a clean pair of sheets"—I took them out, ready for the bed—my mistress said, "Do not stop longer"—I put the clean shirt in my pocket, and forgot to give it to master, as his door was locked; and as I was going out, she said, "Let me see what you have in your pocket?"—I had swept the ring off the carpet just before we moved—she allowed me to go my sister's funeral—she was angry at my leaving, and said before my face that she would prosecute me, if possible, having told the Magistrate, on Tuesday, she would not.

MRS. RICHARDSON re-examined. I do not know whether she attended her sister's funeral after I found the things—every word she has said is false—I did not know she had robbed me till the Tuesday—she was taken up about four months ago—she had robbed me then to a very large amount—I

did not intend to keep her—I did not suspect her—she laid things about the garden, and said somebody had got into the house—she went and called three policemen in to search the house—she took such dreadful oaths of her innocence, that I thought she could not guilty, and yet I did not intend to keep her, as I thought she could not be trustworthy—when before the Magistrate she owned that she stole the things—I did not know that I could charge her with stealing the sheets, for I did not take them out of her pocket.

JURY. Q. In the course of moving from one house to the other, were you aware that the prisoner had part of the linen in her box? A. No—on my oath, she had not—she got a false key, and took them out while I was out.

WILLIAM LLOYD
re-examined. The prisoner was liberated to attend her sister's funeral, for two days, and afterwards returned—the boxes were locked—I had to force them all—the prisoner was not present when I opened them—I never spoke to her about the dishes.
NOT GUILTY .

1042.
JOSEPH TIMBRELL,
JOHN MALONEY , and
JOHN MARTIN , were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 pair of trow
sers, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Medlicot Thomas.

THOMAS FARRANT . I am a policeman. Last Monday evening, about a quarter before eight o'clock, I was in Golden-square, and saw the these prisoners together—I saw Maloney hand a parcel over to Martin—they walked together to John-street, where Maloney gave it to Timbrell, who had an apron on—he was about to put it in his apron, when I went over, and took it from him—this was about 500 or 600 yards from the prose
cutor's—the parcel contained a pair of trowsers.

JAMES THOMAS . I am brother to Edward Medlicot Thomas, a hosier and glover, at the corner of the Haymarket. These trousers belong to him—they hung inside the door on a nail—I saw them about seven o'clock—I did not see either of the prisoners about.
Timbrell. They hung outside the door.

Martin's Defence.—As I was going towards the square these boys had the trowsers—I asked what they had—they said a pair of trowsers which they had found in Golden-square—I was just going to look at them, when the officer came and took us all three into custody.

TIMBRELL—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

MALONEY—
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Three Months.

MARTIN—
NOT GUILTY .

1043.
WILLIAM THOMAS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of March, 1 pail, value 1s. 2d., the goods of
Charles Krotger.

HENRY SPEIGHT . I live at Mrs. Keene's near the prosecutor's. Last Monday, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I saw the prisoner go in at the prosecutor's private door, which was open, without any things I saw him come out with a pail—I went and told Charles Cook who lives there with the prosecutor—we went after him, and overtook him with the pail.
CHARLES COOK . I live with Mr. Krotger, a cheesemonger. Speight come and gave me information—I missed the pail from the end of the passage—I pursued the prisoner, and took him with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
(The prisoner pleaded distress.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 63.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: Confined Eight Days.

1044.
DAVID EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 box, value 1s., 3 lbs. of copper tubing, value 2s., the goods of
George Frederick Eckstein, another his masters.

GEORGE FREDERICK ECKSTEIN .—I am an ironmonger, and live in High Holborn. The prisoner has been about four years in my employ as bell-hanger—he was taken up on account of my property being found on him.

HENRY GILES . I am a policeman. I stopped the prisoner in Holborn, nearly opposite his master's shop. with this property in his tool-bag which I produce—his master desired me to stop him—he was going out with a job.
GEORGE THORNTON . I am a policeman. I searched the prisoner's lodging—he told me it was his lodging—I there found this tin box under the bed, which his master claims.

GEORGE FREDERICK ECKSTEIN
re-examined I gave the prisoner in charge on Saturday, about quarter to one o'clock—i searched his lodging after
wards—I got my brother to mark this copper on the premises, and about two hours after it was missing—i then ran after the prisoner and had him stopped, and it was found in his bag—it is our property—it is worth 2s.—he bore a very good character, and has been with me seven or eight years.

Prisoner's Defence. I am in the habit of working in the shop, where there are seven or eight men—sometimes I am sent out without my bag, and sometimes with it—when I was stopped by the policeman, I was not aware there was any copper in the bag—I have no doubt some of the men put it there—I think some of them had some spite against me.

Jury to MR. ECKSTEIN. Q. Have all your men bags alike? A. No; some of them have—no man put the copper into the prisoner's bag—I had information, and sent him out on a job, and went with my brother and marked the copper in my box—he had his bag out with him then—when he returned he was sent out again, and then he put it into bag—there was no spite on the part of his shopmates.

GUILTY. Aged 34—Recommended to mercy —
Confined There Months.

1045.
JOHN REEVE was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 decanter, value 5s., the goods of
Frederick Hingston.

THOMAS BENTLEY . I was in the Wheatsheaf-yard, on Islington Green, on Saturday, and saw a person carrying a decanter—he delivered it to the prisoner, who ran off with it—I followed him about one hundred yards, and secured him—I saw a ticket on the decanter, and I had seen it in the prosecutors shop for some time—the person who delivered it to him made his escape—I did not see him take it from the shop—they were about two yards from the prosecutor's shop when it was delivered to the prisoner.

HENRY BENJAMIN SEYMOUR . I heard the cry of "Stop their" and saw the prisoner with the decanter in his hand, and Bentley pursuing him—I saw him deposit the decanter in Mr. Hingston's window—I took it up, and delivered it to Mrs. Hingston.

CHARLOTTE HINGSTON . I am the wife Frederick Hingston, who keeps, a saleshop. This is our decanter—it stood inside the shop on a side board—the prisoner is not the person who took it—I do not know any thing of him.

prisoner's Defence I was standing there, and a lad came and shoved the decanter down by the side of me—I stepped across the way with it, and put it in the window, and ran away—I do not know who the lad was—I saw a label on it, and put it down directly.

GUILTY . Aged 19—
Confined Three Months.

1046.
THOMAS BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 2 shillings, 2 pennies, and 2 halfpence, the monies of
David Genese, from his person.

DAVID GENESE . I am of the Jewish persuasion, and am a glass-cutter. Last Friday night, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I felt in with a girl, who accosted me just by Shire-lane—I took her to No. 7, Shire-lane up one pair of stairs—I was sober—I remained with her four or five minutes—I had agreed to give her any money—where I had been in the room four or five minutes somebody came to the door—I had taken no liberties with the girl—I wanted to leave the room—she would not let me, and put her back to the door—she wanted me to give here the money first—I tried to get away, and she called out some name—the prisoner and five or six woman came up and surrounded me—the prisoner stood in front of me, and said, "Why don't you pay the girl?"—and felt my waistcoat pocket—when he found which pocket the money was in be put his hand in—I caught hold of his hand, but he got my money out—and he and the women threw me out of the room directly, and nearly threw me down stairs—when I got to the bottom of the stairs I was thrown out of the door into the lane, and the shut—a policeman came, by, and I told him what had happened—I said I should stop, though the policeman went away—he came back in about twenty minutes, and at that moments the prisoner came out with a hot poker—i laid hold of it, but, feeling it warm, I let it go, and the policeman took him into custody—the prisoner struck me when he came out of the house—the women in the room were all pulling me, some one way and some another, while the prisoner took my money—he took two shilling and some half-pence—I had one shil
ling left—I held the shilling in my hand, at the bottom of my pocket.
Prisoner Q. Am I the person who came into the room? A. Yes-you had no coat at the time—I said at the station-house that you might have had drawers on—I did not mention about a waistcoat.

WILLIAM SIMMONDS . I am a policeman. I was on duty, and saw the prosecutor—he appeared to be sober—he told me he been robbed of two shillings, and was turned out of the house; and in about ten minutes after I took the prisoner into custody—I never saw him before that night—he had his great coat on when I took him—it is a b—u-house—I found one shilling on him and thirteen duplicates.
Prisoner I have witness in my defence.

ELIZABETH WILLIAM . I am single, and live at no. 7, Shire-lane. It is a lodging-house for girls to live in—they out the rooms for girls—I live in the first floor, and have done so for the last three months—I met the prosecutor in Fleet-street, just by Temple-bar—he cam up and said "Where are you going?"—I said, "Home."—he said, "Have you got a room of your own?"—I said, "Yes"—and took him up-stairs—he said he would give me two or three shillings, instead of which he only gave me one shilling—he had satisfaction for it, and then tried to wrench the shilling out of my hand because I would not let him stop any longer—he caught me by the throat—I hallooed out "Murder"—and two or three young women came up stairs, and young man came up, but that was not the prisoner—the prosecutor could not get the shilling from me—he threw me down violently—I don't know the young man's name who came up—I never saw him before—he was in his drawers and shirt—he was quite a stranger—he came down and pulled the prosecutor away from me, and took his hands from my throat—the prosecutor tore my shawl all to pieces—the young man is here—i will swear the prisoner was not there—I did not see him—he was not there at all—he never came of the house—there was a violent knocking at the door, and he went to know what was wanted—he was stirring fire, and went to ask what was the matter—I did not run down stairs till he was taken in charge—I never saw the poker—no man went to the door with a poker, that I saw—there are poker in all the rooms—there was no fire in my room—only one of the girls are here, as I could not tell who they were hardly—the prisoner was not in the houses at all—I can swear he was not there—I can, indeed—I had my shilling after all—the man took no money from the prosecutor at all—he took my shawl and pulled him away from me—the prosecutor did not lose a half
penny—nobody took hold of his waistcoat pocket—I never saw the man before.

GEORGE WEST . I am a coach-trimmer, and live in Great New-street, Fet
ter-lane. I work there now—I was in this house, in Shire-lane, with a young woman who is behind—she was quite a stranger—I was at the top of the house, in bed and asleep—I went to bed about ten o'clock—(I was in the house once before—i do not know one of the girls)—I was asleep, and heard a tremendous noise, and call of "Murder"—the young woman said, "For God's sake go down, and see what is the hatter"—I put on my trowsers, and pushed the door open—I ran in, and he got this woman down, and nearly strangled her—I got between them and parted them—I said, "What is the matter?"—he said, "I gave her a shilling, and I will have it back again"—the girl said, "You shall not"—I said, "Do not have a piece of work here"—there were blows struck amongst them, but I kept the blows off him, and off the girl—another girl came in, and I kept the blows off for peace—they both fought like devils—I kept them off, and said, "You had better go away young man"—I said, "What have you got round your arm?"—he had the girls's shawl—I said, "Go away; I will see you shall not be hurt"—the shawl was given up, and I saw him safe out of the room—I was in my drawers—I never saw the prosecutor in my life before—as soon as I put him of the room, I went up-stairs again, and do not know what happened afterwards—I went to sleep, and heard no more of the case—I came down with nothing but shirt and drawers on, and had no waistcoat or night-cap on—the prisoner's hair is black—I have light hair—I was never in a row before in my life, but I do not like to hear a female call murder—I saw no poker—there was no fire in our room—I was never in the other rooms—there was no fire in the girls's room, nor any poker—there might be a poker and tongs, but the poker never stirred out of its place—i did not take the poker myself—that happened down stairs—the prisoner was in the house down stairs—I never saw him. but it appears he was in the house—it appears that he went out and struck the man—i will swear the prisoner was not in the room at all—I believe he was in the room down, stairs, in the parlour; because, when the prosecutor knocked at the door, he went out to know what was the matter I have been told so but I never saw—i have been to the house since I left my address there, in case I should be wanted on behalf of the innocent man—I left word where to come to me—the prosecutor was not robbed at all—he gave a shillings, and wanted to rob the girl of her shawl—I did not turn him out—I never went down stairs—I did not go to the street door.

---- ----. I am an unfortunate girl, and live in Shire-lane. I know the last witness, by his being with me Friday night—I met him in Fleet-street—I had seen him once or twice before, but not to know his name—he only slept with me one—Friday night was the first time I had any thing to say him—I have spoken to him in the street before, but nothing further—I was never with him in that house before—I am quite sure of that—except seeing him in the street, he was quite a stranger to me be
fore I met him—about ten o'clock there was a great noise, and I directly said there is murder being called—he put on his drawers, and went down stairs—he was down stairs a quarter of an hour—when he came up he told me what bad passed down stairs—I kept in bed—I did not get out—I know the prisoner by this living down stairs with his wife in the parlour—I never knew anything further of him than peace and quietness—I never saw any harm of him—I do not know what age his wife is: she is older than I am—she is not the mistress of the house—I pay rent to the lady next door—she rents two houses—I cannot tell how his wife gets her living—they live in the parlour—I dare say they have a poker is their room—I have been there a month—he lived there before I went—I cannot say how many girls were in the house at the time, for I was not out of my bed—there are about seven rooms in the house, I think—I lodge up-stairs, at the top of the house—the door of the house is always open, for people to come in and out.

DAVID GENESE
re-examined Q. Did you give the girl any money at all. A. No; I did not—it is all false about the shilling—the prisoner came out with the hot poker just as the policeman came up, and passed it across my face—I am sure he is the man who rifled my waistcoat pocket—he is the man who came in with the woman, and surrounded me—the man who had the poker is the man who had the money out of my pocket—it is im
possible to mistake the witness for the prisoner—I saw no man in the house but the prisoner—I was perfectly sober.

WILLIAM SIMMONDS
re-examined I saw the prisoner with the poker.

Prisoner I can account for having the poker in my hand—I was going to bed—there was a knocking and kicking at the street-door—I was stir
ring the fire to go the bed, and went to the door, but not with the intent to do the man any mischief—I opened the door, and said, "What are you doing at the door"—he directly said to the policeman, "I have been robbed of 2s"—I did not take the poker with a view of burning him—I was not up the stairs, nor near the stairs—I work for Mr. Mason, of Newgate-market.

GUILTY —
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1047.
JOHN WARD was indicted
for stealing on the 8th of March, 1 hearth-rug, value 5s., the goods of
Henry Chappell.
HENRY CHAPPELL . I am a linen-draper. On Tuesday evening, the 8th of March, I lost a health-rug from my door at Brentford.

ANN HILL . I am a labouring man's wife, and live in the Ham, New Brentford. On the 8th or 9th of March I and Ann Wigmore were walking up the Ham together, and the prisoner was walking towards his own house—he beckoned to Wigmore, and we went to him—he asked if she wanted to buy a hearth-rug, and said, "Come down to my house, and look at it"—I went there—he took it up off the floor, and put it on the table—Wigmore asked him the price—he said 3s.6d., which she paid him in my presence, and took the rug away—he does not keep any shop—this is the health rug.

JOSEPH DEAN . I am a pawnbroker. On the 8th of March, Mr. Chappell came to me, and said he had lost a rug, and described the private mark, and on Friday week this rug was brought to me by a little girl of the name of Page—the private mark is on it—I stopped it.

THOMAS BANKS (police-constable F 23) On the 9th of March I went to the pawnbrokers—Mrs. Wigmore was there, and I took her to the station-house—in consequence of what she said, I took the prisoner at the corner of the Ham, about one hundred yards from where he lives—he said he bought the rug of a woman that travelled about, and sold it to Mrs. Wig
more—he described the women he bought it of as a short stout woman, rather fresh coloured—he told he bought it at Mr. Piper's. the Six Bells public-house—the Ham is about five hundred yards from Mr. Chap
pell's.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 9th of March, I went into Mr. Piper's at the Six Bells, to take a pint of beer with a man—a travelling woman, with brushes and lines, and other things, came in there—she offered this for sale for 5s.—I at last gave her 3s. 6d.—I took it home, any my daughter acolded me for buying such a little thing—I said, "I will sell it again," and in going up the Ham, I saw Mrs. Wigmore, and she gave me 3s. 6d. for it.

STEPHEN PLAYFORD . I am a blacksmith, living at Brentford. I know the prisoner by sight—on the 9th March I was at the Six Bells public-house with him—a woman came in with some brushes and other things—she had a rug, something similar to this—the prisoner bought it for 3s. 6d—there were one or two other persons in the house—this was between ten and eleven o'clock as near as I can think.

COURT. Q. Did you know this woman? A. No—she was carrying these things—I did not see any cart, nor any one to help her—I don't know how far that is from Mr. Chappell's—the Six Bells up against Brentford Bridge.

JOHN SERGEANT. I am a coal-dealer, and live in Webb's-lane, Ham
mersmith. I am not acquainted with the prisoner—I called in at the Six Bells about half-past ten o'clock in the morning—I saw the travelling wo
man come in with wares to sell, and I saw the prisoner buy the rug.

COURT. Q. What passed? A. It was first offered to me—she asked 5s., I think—I said I did not want to purchase any thing of the sort—she then went to the prisoner, and offered it to him—I had notice to attend here on Monday last—the prisoner sent up me to attend—I call twice a-week at this public-house.

ELEANOR COX . I am the prisoner's daughter. I remember his bringing home this rug on the 9th of March, between ten eleven o'clock—it did not suit me—it was too samll—he said he would sell it to some one else.
NOT GUILTY .

1048.
SUSAN PALMER was indicted
for feloniously receiving of an evil-disposed person, 1 pair of half-boots, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Lewis Stephens Lyne.

ANN HEARD . I am servant to Mr. Lewis Stephens Lyne, of Brick's-buildings, Hoxton. He is a silk-broker—the prisoner was occasionally. employed as char-woman—she had access to the room in which I slept—I missed from there a pair of child's shoes—these are them—the child has been dead five years, and these were put with some other shoes—they are worth 2s. 6d.—I missed them three weeks ago last shoes—they was charged with the offence last Thursday week—she had been to the house in the mean time.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82) I apprehended the prisoner, and told her it was on suspicion of receiving some property which her daughter had stolen—she declared she was innocent, and knew nothing at all about it—I asked if she had bought any tickets—she said, no, she left them at home—I said she had not, as I had been and searched her house—I took her to the station-house—a purse and some duplicates were founds on her—one to these relates to the shoes—she told me they were her child's master's property; that her daughter stole the shoes, gave them to here, and she pawned them—I made her no promise or threat.
Prisoner. I had a very sick house—I took them myself, and pledged them myself, because I could not support my family.

WILLIAM ASTELL . I am apprentice to Mr. Essex, of Islington, a pawn
broker. I produce a pair of child's shoes, pledged on the 12th of March by a female, in the name of "Mary Palmer"—this duplicate, found on the prisoner is the one given for them.

ANN HEARD . The prisoner daughter is nine years old—she is in ser
vice at my master's—she was charged with stealing these things.

Prisoner They shut her in a room two policeman—she was so frightened, she confessed it, but it was me that took them. Witness. The prisoner worked four there, and bad four children, she had 3s. a-day for washing; and half-a-crown for charring at our house, and her living.

GEORGE KEMP
re-examined Her home is all in poverty, but t is all her own fault.
NOT GUILTY .

1049.
THEODORE CHANNELL and
PHILLIP CORK were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January, 90lbs. weight of pork value 2l. the goods of
James Morgan Strachan.

HENRY BEARE . I am servant to Mr. James Strachan, of Teddington. His dairy was broken into in the month of January, 1834, and some legs of pork and other pieces cut for salting, were stolen—I know nothing of the particulars.

WILLIAM ALLAWAY TEDDINGTON . I am a police-sergeant. I applied for a warrant for Phillip Cork and John Stuckey—I went to Cork's house, on Twickenham-common—I told him I wanted him on a charge of felony—I read my warrant to him—he said, "Why did you come at this late hour of the day—why did you not come in the morning?"—I was about to put the handcuffs on him—he said, "I will go without them"—I said, "You must have them on"—he then wanted to go into the next room for his jacket—I said his wife could get it—a constable who was with me gave it him—he seized this knife, and said the would not go, and he would stab the first man that come near him—I seized him by the collar and got him in the corner of the room—he kicked the other constable, and struck me—we got the handcuffs on one hand and took him—I went to get Stuckey—I could not find him—I returned to the lock-up place, and searched Cork—he said "You want another person, don't you?"—he said it was Channell—I looked him very bard in the face—he said, I am guilty—I mean to plead guilty before the magistrate'—I looked him up, and and left him.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you set a man of the name of Seth upon making inquiries? A. I had not—I knew he had made in
quiries—he is a police-constable, who apprehended Channell—the other person was taken on Channell's information—I believe Seth did not-under
take that Channell should be admitted as a witness—this was two years ago last January—the prisoner have not been living in the neighbourhood, to my knowledge—I have been three weeks in the place—the man tried all in his power to use the knife—he kicked my brother-officer, and struck me—he said he was guilty, and meant to plead guilty before the magistrate—that was on Wednesday, and Thursday he was taken before the magis
trate.

COURT. Q. Have you the warrant here that you read to him? A. No. 1 left it at the magistrate's office—I read the warrant naming Mr. Strachan—no mention was made of what had happened to Mr. Strachan—I cannot recollect the words I used.
GEORGE CLARK . I am clerk to the magistrate at Brentford. I know of no promises held out to prisoner Channell—I have no reason to believe there were any.
